review.title: Cosolver2B: An Efficient Local Search Heuristic for the Travelling Thief Problem
review.abstract: Real-world problems are very difficult to optimize. However, many researchers have been solving benchmark problems that have been extensively investigated for the last decades even if they have very few direct applications. The Traveling Thief Problem (TTP) is a NP-hard optimization problem that aims to provide a more realistic model. TTP targets particularly routing problem under packing/loading constraints which can be found in supply chain management and transportation. In this paper, TTP is presented and formulated mathematically. A combined local search algorithm is proposed and compared with Random Local Search (RLS) and Evolutionary Algorithm (EA). The obtained results are quite promising since new better solutions were found.
histories: 12th ACS/IEEE International Conference on Computer Systems and Applications (AICCSA) 2015. November 17-20, 2015
review.COMMENTS: 12th ACS/IEEE International Conference on Computer Systems and Applications (AICCSA) 2015. November 17-20, 2015

metadata.title: Cosolver2B: An Efficient Local Search Heuristic for the Travelling Thief Problem

sections.text: This year, it has come to the point where there is only one occasion when there is a scandal, and that is when there is a scandal.

sections.heading: II. BACKGROUND
sections.text: In this section we present some background information about TTP. The problem is formulated and an abstract algorithm is presented.

sections.heading: A. The Travelling Thief Problem
sections.text: In it, we formulate the Traveler Thief Problem (TTP), which combines two other known benchmark problems (namely, the Traveler Seller Problem (TSP) and the Knapsack Problem (KP). In TTP, we look at n cities and the associated distance matrix (dij). There are m elements scattered throughout these cities, each element k has a gain pk and a weight wk. A thief with his knapsack will visit all these cities (once and only once) and pick up some items to fill his knapsack. We note that the maximum capacity of the knapsack, vmin and vmax are the minimum and maximum possible speed wk. As an overall value, we also consider the following restrictions and parameters: • Each item is available in only one city. We note {Ai} the availability vector, Ai {1,..., n} contains the reference to the city that contains the element i. • We assume that the knapsack problem is corresponding to the city price.

sections.heading: B. Cosolver
sections.text: Cosolver is an abstract algorithm proposed in [2] to solve TTP. The idea behind the algorithm is simple. Disassemble the overall problem and solve the components separately using a fitness function that takes into account the interdependence between the two components. Thus, TTP is broken down into the following problems at an initial solution (x0, z0).1) The Travelling Salesman with Knapsack Problem (TSKP): is to find the best tour x, "which in combination with the most recently found commission plan z" optimizes the TTP target function G. Since the overall profit function also does not depend on the tour, instead of maximizing G, we can consider minimizing the total travel cost T (see Equation 3). T (x, z) = R х f (x, z) (3) 2) The knapsack problem on the route (KRP): is to find the best commission plan "that maximizes the total gain" when combining the last frame with the Cosolver.

sections.heading: III. PROPOSED APPROACH
sections.text: In this section, we propose an algorithm that implements the Cosolver framework and uses some techniques proposed in [11].

sections.heading: A. Solution initialization
sections.text: For TTP, the initial solution has a major impact on the search algorithm, so the initialization strategy should be chosen carefully. In our implementation, we use a heuristic approach to initialize both the tour and the picking plan. First, the tour is generated using a good TSP algorithm such as the Lin-Kernighan heuristic [6] or the ant colony optimization algorithm [5], and then the picking plan is initialized with the following approach: 1) The fill heuristic proposed in [11] is used to fill the knapsack with items according to three fitness approximations. 2) A simple bit-flip search on inserted items is performed to eliminate some useless items from the picking plan using the objective function.We will call this heuristic insertion & elimination.

sections.heading: B. Complexity reduction techniques
sections.text: Our algorithm uses the following complexity reduction techniques: 1) TSKP Neighborhood Reduction: The Delaunay triangulation [4] is used as a candidate generator for 2-OPT heuristics; this strategy was also proposed in [11].2) Objective Value Restoration: Instead of using the objective function to calculate the objective value of neighbors, this value can be restored by tracking time and weight information in each city on the tour. • Time Register (treg): a vector containing the current time in each city on the tour. • Weight Register (wacc): a vector containing the current weight in each city on the tour. • Time Register (treg): a vector containing the additional time in each city on the tour. • Weight Register (wreg): a vector containing the additional weight in each city.

sections.heading: C. Proposed algorithm
sections.text: Our heuristics, Cosolver2B, is based on local search algorithms and implements the Cosolver framework. In addition to the techniques presented above, we use 2-OPT heuristics to solve the TSKP and a bit-flip search to solve the KRP. The algorithm is used in the flow chart in Figure 4.1http: / / cs.adelaide.edu.au / optlog / CEC2015Comp / The algorithm starts with a tour generated by LinKernigh heuristics. Insertion & elimination of heuristics is then used to initialize the picking plan. The tour and picking plan obtained is then given to the TSKP optimizer, which attempts to improve the current tour by means of 2-OPT heuristics. The resulting tour is combined with the current picking plan and given to the KRP optimizer, which uses a simple bit flip to find a decent picking plan.

sections.heading: IV. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: We tested our algorithm on 15 TTP instances of different sizes [13]. The results obtained are compared with RLS and EA, which were suggested in the same essay. We implemented two versions of Cosolver2B. The first is most suitable (also known as the best improvement), which scans the entire neighborhood on a particular iteration and selects the best neighbor. The second is firstly suitable (also known as the first improvement), which stops the neighborhood search.Since our algorithms are deterministic, one run per instance is sufficient. The algorithms have a maximum runtime limit of 600 seconds. Note that our implementation uses the Java platform, and the tests are performed on a core i3-2370M CPU 2.40 GHz machine with 4 GB of RAM, using Linux. On the other hand, due to their random behavior, 30 runs per instance were performed with RLS and EA. The tests on EA and RLS were performed on another machine.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Our approach is based on the Cosolver framework and complexity reduction techniques. The experimental results show promising results both in terms of solution quality and runtime. The good performance of Cosolver2B and the MALTS memetic algorithm on a very large scale [11] shows how important it is to make strong assumptions about the problem area when it comes to multi-component problems. In addition, we are committed to improving our algorithm in terms of space exploration and runtime through the use of more sophisticated search heuristics.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
sections.text: The authors would like to thank the following people who contributed their useful comments to this work: Asmae El Ghazi, Aziz Ouaarab and Mehdi El Krari.

referenceMentions.context: The travelling thief problem (TTP) is a novel NP-hard problem introduced in [1] to provide a model that better represents real-world problems.
In [3], the authors explain why there is a gap between the work done by the Evolutionary Computation researchers and real-world applications.

Examples of other realistic problems with multiple interdependent sub-problems include most supply chain optimization problems [7], [8], routing problems with loading constraints such as 2L-CVRP and 3L-CVRP [9], [10], [3], and water tank delivery [14].

An Evolutionary Algorithm and a Random Local Search were proposed in [13] to provide a starting point to other researchers.
In [2], an approach named Cosolver was introduced to solve TTP by separating the sub-problems and managing a communication between them.
Lastly, an interesting work on TTP introduces many complexity reduction techniques in order to solve very large instances in a time budget of 10 minutes [11].
In this paper, we follow the ideas proposed in [2] and [11] to propose further improvements and introduce an algorithm based on the Cosolver framework that can solve TTP instances efficiently.
In this paper, we follow the ideas proposed in [2] and [11] to propose further improvements and introduce an algorithm based on the Cosolver framework that can solve TTP instances efficiently.
As shown in [1], [11], optimizing the sub-problems in isolation (even to optimality) does not guarantee finding good solutions for the overall problem.
As shown in [1], [11], optimizing the sub-problems in isolation (even to optimality) does not guarantee finding good solutions for the overall problem.
Cosolver is an abstract algorithm proposed in [2] to solve TTP.
In this section, we propose an algorithm that implements the Cosolver framework and uses some techniques proposed in [11].
Firstly, the tour is generated using a good TSP algorithm such as the Lin-Kernighan heuristic [6] or the Ant Colony Optimization algorithm [5].
Firstly, the tour is generated using a good TSP algorithm such as the Lin-Kernighan heuristic [6] or the Ant Colony Optimization algorithm [5].
1) The insertion heuristic proposed in [11] is used to fill the knapsack with items according to three fitness approximations.
1) TSKP neighborhood reduction: The Delaunay triangulation [4] is used as a candidate generator for the 2-OPT heuristic.
This strategy was also proposed in [11].
A similar technique named incremental evaluation was proposed in [11].
3) Objective function calculation: The objective function has a complexity of O(m ∗ n) as proposed in [12], where m is the number of items and n is the number of cities.
We tested our algorithm on 15 TTP instances of various sizes [13].

The good performance of Cosolver2B and the memetic algorithm MALTS on very large scale instances [11] proves the importance of making strong assumptions about the problem domain when dealing with multi-component problems.
